Documents: Declaration of the Rights of Man and of the Citizen
Reformers: Jean-Jacques Rousseau, Marquis de Condorcet, Abbé Siéyès, Olympe de Gouges
Groups: The Third Estate, The National Assembly
Economic Conditions: Economic stagnation, mounting debt, food shortages
Popular Reactions: Calls for radical reforms and an end to France’s absolute monarchy
Long-term Influence: The replacement of absolute monarchy with a constitutional monarchy, the formation of democratic nations and the advancement of universal human rights throughout Europe
Achievements: Abolition of feudalism and related privileges, the Declaration of the Rights of Man and of the Citizen, nationalization of Church properties, decentralization of republican government.
